rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:1
rsbNotes.text: 21:1 the offering box. In the court of the women there were thirteen trumpet-shaped collection boxes with inscriptions showing the use to which donations would be put.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:2
rsbNotes.text: 21:2 poor. An unusual word (only here in New Testament) meaning “very poor.” Her total livelihood (v. 4) was two copper coins of the lowest value (see text note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:5
rsbNotes.text: 21:5 noble stones. See note Mark 13:2.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:6
rsbNotes.text: 21:6 This was fulfilled during the destruction of Jerusalem in a.d. 70.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:8
rsbNotes.text: 21:8 I am He. False teachers will claim to be the Christ.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:9
rsbNotes.text: 21:9 the end. The end of all things. Some sections of this discourse refer to the destruction of Jerusalem in a.d. 70 and others to Jesus’ coming at the end of the age (Mark 13:4 note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:12
rsbNotes.text: 21:12 synagogues. Synagogues were centers for discipline as well as places of worship.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:13
rsbNotes.text: 21:13 Trouble for the church also means opportunity to bear witness.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:16–19
rsbNotes.text: 21:16–19 This passage is a strong affirmation of God’s overriding control. For some of His followers there will be a martyr’s death, for others deliverance. Either way, God is bringing His purposes to pass.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:20
rsbNotes.text: 21:20 Jerusalem. This section refers to the destruction of the city, not the end time (v. 9 note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:21
rsbNotes.text: 21:21 flee to the mountains. People would normally flee to a walled city for shelter from an invading army, but Jerusalem is doomed. People must run away from it, not try to enter it.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:22
rsbNotes.text: 21:22 vengeance. Not meaningless suffering, but the divine penalty.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:23
rsbNotes.text: 21:23 Alas. The siege of Jerusalem in a.d. 70 in fact brought extreme suffering.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:24
rsbNotes.text:
21:24 the times of the Gentiles. This may mean the time when the Gentiles will have their triumph over Israel, or the time when the gospel is preached to the Gentiles, or both.

fulfilled. A divine purpose will be worked out (cf. Rom. 11:1–32).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:25–26
rsbNotes.text: 21:25, 26 Attention moves to the Second Coming of Christ (v. 9 note). It will be preceded by signs that will puzzle many.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:27
rsbNotes.text: 21:27 coming. Jesus’ return will be a coming in splendor to reign.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 21:28
rsbNotes.text: 21:28 redemption. This word means deliverance on payment of a price. Jesus paid the price at Calvary, and He here looks forward to the final fulfillment of what that deliverance means.
